title: small business saturday chance shoppers
story: NewsSmall business Saturday is a chance for shoppers to support local independent shopsThere are a whopping .million small firms across the UK - from butchers and bakers to pet groomers and pubsShareCommentsByGraham HiscottHead of Business:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsBarber shop owner Dimitri Loizi says customers like the fact theyre not a big chain"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere are a whopping .million small firms across the UK - from butchers and bakers to pet groomers and pubs. They’re the backbone of the economy, and employ more than  million people. Yet their contribution is often overlooked. But today marks Small Business Saturday, when the public is encouraged to make a special effort to support those in their area. They include small shops, which the Daily Mirror has also been backing as part of our High Street Fightback campaign. But Small Business Saturday is also about shining a light on other small entrerprises, from plumbers to dentists, local garages to physios, manufacturers to designers, and online as well and ‘bricks and mortar’. The first event took place in America in , when the world was recovering from the financial crisis. It got a big boost with the backing of then US President Barack Obama. The venture was supported by credit card giant American Express which helped it launch here in . It is estimated that nearly poundm was spent during last year’s Small Business Saturday, up from poundm in  and poundm in . This year’s campaign has included a -stop bus tour stretching from Scotland to Cornwall, to drum-up support ahead of the event itself.   Michelle Ovens MBE, director of Small Business Saturday, said: “We have just had Black Friday, a day just about deep discounts that can be hard for small businesses to match. “Small Business Saturday is the antidote for this. “We are encouraging people to come out in force to celebrate the Small businesses, up and down the country, who have been working hard all year to provide great service, and huge value to communities now is the time for us all to show our appreciation to the positive impact they have on our economy and society.” Mike Cherry, National Chairman of the Federation of Small Businesses, said: “Many of these firms are facing mounting pressures from increasing business rates, online shopping and future uncertainty post-Brexit while, at the same time contributing so much to their local communities. “Which is why Small Business Saturday is a great moment to encourage everyone to show their favourite local businesses some love, especially in the run up to the festive season.”   These are just a few of the business that need support...Dimitri Loizi, , owner of The Barber Club in The Lanes area of Brighton, plus another in Croydon.He said: “The biggest challenge when you first start up in business is the initial start up costs. But I love the fact we’re now ingrained in the hub of the local community. “We have other business owners who come in. The clients like the fact we’re not yet another big chain. We also recommend bars locally people should go to so it’s all about helping each other.”Addiscotts Dog Food - Dorset-based specialist pet food company. Sauce  Brown -a menswear shop and business based in the former mining town of Annesley Woodhouse in North Nottinghamshire. Kuk Shades - An online beachwear business based in Cumbria. Artie Craftie - a quirky and art and craft supplies shop based in Blaenavon, South Wales. Alexander Byron - a family run independent baby shop in Grimsby. Hay Hampers, a family-run business in Lincolnshire, producing affordable fresh food hampersMany big chains - like smaller shops - are also struggling. But today’s is about focusing attention on these smaller businesses for a change. The easiest way to get involved on the day is make an active decision to shop locally. As part of this year’s event, many small businesses will be running special offers, so it’s worth checking out what deals are out there. One way is to visit the Small Business Saturday websitewhich has a tool that lets you search for small shops and other firms in your area that are taking part. However, the campaign isn’t restricted to these businesses - it’s about supporting all small firms, whether they are involved or not.   What   Lots of local councils are offering free parking for Small Business Saturday, so look out for what they are doing. There are also lots of events happening across the UK today. One way to check is to use the hashtag #SmallBizSatUk on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram. Just a few of the events taking place are...West Berkshire council is doing a minibus tour of small businesses in the region. Cannock Chase is putting on a craft market and are offering free market stalls to local small business producers. Various Christmas fairs including in Southwick, Workington and Durham.Free live entertainment on Hucknall High Street in Nottinghamshire Burton Winter Festival in the Market Hall Inverness Victorian Market Grangetown seasonal street market in Cardf. Gabriel’s Wharf on the south bank in London are having a big “magical Christmas event” focused around small businesses.TipsDon’t assume small business are more expensive than big business - lots offer great value. Remember that services as well as products contribute to the local community and economy. Labour is launching a “listening campaign” to get a better idea of what is needed to boost the high street. Eleven members of the Shadow Cabinet - including Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell - will be taking part in events on Saturday. Rebecca Long Bailey Labour’s Shadow Business Secretary, said: “We cannot continue to allow our high streets to decline as they have under the Tories. “I’m proud that Labour members are out in force today listening to local communities so that we can work together across the country to breathe le back into our high streets.”

story: NewsEmirates Boeing  takes off immediately after hard landing during Storm DianaAviation enthusiast Jonathan Winton took the nerve-wracking clip at Newcastle AirportShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video terrying-aborted-landing-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShocking footage shows a plane having to take off immediately after a hard landing forced it to abort its first attempt.The clip was taken by plane enthusiast Jonathan Winton at Newcastle Airport on Thursday. An Emirates Boeing , arriving from Dubai, was caught in heavy crosswinds during Storm Diana. Explaining what happened, Mr Winton posted on YouTube: The wind had been gusting at around  [mph] to kts [mph] this Thursday morning. Having established on the approach for runway  and been cleared to land by the controller, it looked like a normal approach in the challenging crosswinds from the south.  As the  disappeared behind the hedge before touching down, it slammed down onto runway , the spoilers deployed, and the next thing full power was applied for a go around. Ive never seen anything like it here at Newcastle Airport. The aircraft then came in for a second approach and landed safely. Upon landing the aircraft was inspected and initially there was thought to be damage to the rear landing gear. Upon further inspection though it was deemed safe to fly and the aircraft departed Newcastle for Dubai  minutes later than planned. Dai Whittingham, chief executive of the UK Flight Safety Committee, told Mail Online : High winds in themselves are not dangerous but they can certainly be inconvenient, especiallythe wind direction is across the runway.All pilots train to land in high crosswind conditions and will have practiced to the aircraft limits in the simulator. Gardener Mr Winton, , of Alnwick, Northumberland, said: The winds didnt feel particularly strong at first but as we got a bit higher up they suddenly hit.  Im a huge aviation fan so for me it was incredible to watch, but for those with a fear of flying it must have been pretty hair-raising. A spokesperson for Newcastle International Airport confirmed that there were no cancellations or delays as a result of Storm Diana.

story: NewsFatcat rail bosses enjoy bumper % payrise while commuters face % rail fare hikeThe cost of many rail season tickets will increase by more than £ from JanuaryShareCommentsByNick Sommerlad:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsGo Ahead’s chief executive David Brown got paid £.m last year, up %"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain’s fatcat rail bosses enjoyed a bumper % average payrise last year – as commuters were hit by news that their rail fares are being hiked by % next year. The cost of many rail season tickets will increase by more than pound from January despite punctuality slipping to a -year low this summer. The rail industry insisted money from fares is “underpinning the improvements to the railway that passengers want”. But Rail, Maritime and Transport union general secretary Mick Cash said the latest fare rise is “another kick in the teeth for passengers on Britain’s rip-off privatised railways”. A Mirror investigation has found that the best paid bosses of private rail operating franchises pocketed an average salary of pound, – more than double the amount paid every year to Prime Minister Theresa May. That is a payrise of pound, on average from the previous year when rail bosses typically earned pound, each. The Mirror has examined the accounts of  separate rail companies which run Britain’s biggest networks. The company accounts for First Greater Western reveal that the best paid director received pound, last year, including a pound, bonus. That is an increase of % or pound, from the previous year. The best paid director of French owned Keolis , which runs a string of UK rail franchises, got paid pound, last year, a payrise of %.   The best paid Virgin Rail boss took home pound,, up %, despite the collapse of its East Coast rail service with Stagecoach. One director at Govia Thameslink, which faced calls to lose its franchise after delays, got paid pound, last year, up %. The best paid boss of a rail and transport group, Go Ahead’s chief executive David Brown got paid pound.m last year, up %. The RMT’s Mick Cash added: “We are constantly being told there is not enough money to employ station staff and guards but when it comes to boardroom pay on Britain’s rip-off railways the sky’s the limit. “This news will just add to passenger anger after the latest fare hike.” From January  next year, the price of a season ticket from Brighton to London will go up by pound to pound,, while one from Gloucester to Birmingham goes up pound to to pound, and one from Manchester to Liverpool goes up pound to pound,. The average rise will be the second highest since January , according to industry body the Rail Delivery Group . There have been calls for prices to be frozen following chaos caused by the implementation of new timetables in May. Fewer than halfof passengers are satisfied with the value for money of train tickets, according to a survey by watchdog Transport Focus. Its chief executive Anthony Smith said passengers want a reliable service offering better value, adding: “They shouldn’t have to wait any longer for that.   “Some passengers will have memories of the timetable crisis in the summer. We’ve got ongoing very patchy performance. All this is causing problems.” Some % of services failed to meet the industry’s punctuality target in the  months to November . -year-old passenger Verna Dilley, from London, said trains are “incredibly expensive” and fares are “becoming ridiculous”.   She added: “I don’t think it’s value for money. I think quite regularly when you have to stand for a long journey, why should you have to pay a fare ” Paul Plummer, chief executive of the industry body Rail Delivery Group, said: “Money from fares is underpinning the improvements to the railway that passengers want and which ultimately help boost the wider economy. “That means more seats, extra services and better connections right across the country.”   A Department for Transport spokesman said that “any fare increase is unwelcome” but insisted it is “not fair to ask people who do not use trains to pay more for those who do”. He added: “Taxpayers already subsidise the network by more than pound billion a year - meaning that % of our transport budget is spent on the % of journeys that the railway accounts for.” Shadow transport secretary Andy McDonald claimed the increase shows “a Government and rail industry out of touch with passenger concerns”.A spokesman for the Rail Delivery Group, said: “Director’s pay is set according to market rates to attract the people needed to run big,complex safety-critical companies that move millions of passengers every day.”

title: five nations running build royal
story: NewsFive nations in running to build Royal Navy ships - but only one bid is BritishThe MoD said companies from Italy, Spain, Japan and South Korea were in the running for the bumper contract – with a UK consortium also shortlistedShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  NOV NewsHMS-Sutherland pictured in  - as firms from five nations battle it out for contracts "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFive nations are in the running to build Royal Navy supply ships, the Ministry of Defence has revealed. The competition to design and construct the Fleet Solid Support vessels for the Royal Fleet Auxiliary unleashed a major political row after the Tories claimed they were not warships – even though they will be armed and steam into battle zones. That meant the poundbillion deal to build two, possibly three vessels, could be offered to foreign shipyards – potentially denying British workers and firms a massive windfall. The MoD said companies from Italy, Spain, Japan and South Korea were in the running for the bumper contract – with a UK consortium also shortlisted.   The British team is made up of leading manufacturing and engineering companies Babcock, BAE Systems, Cammell Laird and Rolls-Royce. They join Italian firm Fincantieri, Spanish company Navantia, Japan Marine United Corporation, and Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine Engineering of South Korea as the firms invited to submit a tender for the competition. Defence Minister Stuart Andrew said: “The widespread interest in this competition shows that our Royal Navy and Royal Fleet Auxiliary remain among the most prestigious in the world.   “These support ships will be vital for supporting our formidable Queen Elizabeth-class carriers and will ensure our warships can deploy in a range of challenging environments and across huge distances, wherever they are in the world.” The winning bidder will be announced in . Unions and Labour have called for the ships to be built in Britain to boost UK industry and give a steady workflow to skilled British employees. The vessels will restock Navy destroyers, frigates and aircraft carriers at seas with food, ammunition and other supplies.   They are due to enter service in . Shipbuilding and Engineering Union general secretary Ian Waddell said: “The Government are insisting that these ships are not warships so that they can open the contracts up to international competition in order to save money.   “The reality is that since the end of the aircraft carrier project  shipbuilding jobs have been lost in the UK, one yard has been closed and another is under threat. “By classying these ships, which carry weapons and support the carrier strike capability, as warships, which they do in other EU countries, we can design, manufacture and maintain these ships in the UK and guarantee jobs for a generation.

title: incredible recording girl 4 who
story: NewsIncredible recording of girl, , who helped save mum by calling Kaitlyn Wright, from Askerswell, near Dorchester, Dorset, has made mother-of-three Charlene "the proudest mum in the world"ShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video incredible-recording-girl--who-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA four-year-old girl who rang  when her mum started having seizures at home has been praised for her quick-thinking actions.Kaitlyn Wright told the emergency services operator mum Charlene was having a fit and that she needed to look after her. When the call handler asked the youngstershe was there alone, the youngster replied: Its just me. And a dog and a kitten. Kaitlyn tried to direct the operator to the family home by telling them to go down the big hill and up the other side. The operator was able to trace the call and ambulance paramedics rushed to the address in Askerswell, near Dorchester, Dorset.  Luckily Charlene recovered by the time the ambulance turned up  minutes later and she was checked over. The -year-old said today: I just cant explain how very proud I am of Kaitlyn. I am the proudest mum in the world right now, shes just wonderful. It was quite scary for Kaitlyn to see me have a fit but she was so calm and chilled about it. Charlene suffers from fibromyalgia syndromewhich leaves her in constant pain and prone to regular seizures.  Because of her condition she had spoken to all three of her children and practiced how to call for an ambulance so they knew what to do in an emergency. Charlene said she is rarely home alone with just Kaitlyn but on this occasion her older daughter Ky, , and Kayden, , were out. Charlene said: Kaitlyns dad had seen her in the morning and then brought her back home. He askedI wanted some shopping and I said yes. Kaitlyn wanted to stay at home with me, we wouldnt normally be at home just the two of us, I try to avoid it in case something does happen.  I was lying in bed and felt quite comfortable at the time but Id had a bad week and had been in a lot of pain. The pain gets so much that my body basically reboots like a computer because it cant handle the level of pain. The next thing I knew was the paramedic looking at me. I dont really remember much. Ive been having the seizures for about five or six months and taught all the kids what to do, weve practiced on the phone, pretending to call  so theyd know what to do.  During the phone call Kaitlyn tried to direct them to the house,telling them to go down the big hill from the A and up the other side. I dont think she realises how great she was but I told her well done and what a great job she had done. Today Kaitlyn and her mum are due to visit the South Western Ambulance Service control centre near Bristol to the call handler the youngster spoke.  Kaitlyn will also been given a special certicate for her actions. A spokesman for the South Western Ambulance Service said: During the call Kaitlyn showed extraordinary bravery, presence of mind, and wisdom beyond her years. Thankfully, her mum made a recovery, and didnt need paramedics to treat her.

title: margaret thatcher turned back lockerbie
story: NewsMargaret Thatcher turned her back on Lockerbie victims to cut compensation billTop Tories meeting in No were wrongly told none of the dead passengers were BritishShareCommentsByNick Sommerlad:,  NOV NewsMargaret Thatcher’s cold-hearted Cabinet discussed minimising the cost of compensating Lockerbie disaster - hours after it happened "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMargaret Thatcher’s cold-hearted Cabinet discussed minimising the cost of compensating Lockerbie disaster victims just hours after the terror attack. Top Tories meeting in No were wrongly told none of the dead passengers were British and that the houses of victims on the ground would be insured, a confidential memo reveals. It would emerge  of the  passengers on the doomed flight were British, as was one of the  crew. Another  perished in their homes when wreckage from Pan Am Flight  hit the Scottish village of Lockerbie  years ago this month. Jim Swire, , whose daughter Flora died in the bombing, described the document as “callous and calculating”. It comes as another confidential memo revealed officials thought families of Lockerbie terror attack victims needed “careful watching”. Relatives, including Dr Swire – a vocal critic of the Government’s response to the attack – claim they have been repeatedly bugged by security services. The Mirror has unearthed a confidential minute of the Cabinet meeting at .am on December , , the morning after the tragedy.  Ministers were told “there would be a general expectation that a disaster fund would be established” that “the Government would contribute to it” and that “it would be a mistake to preicate over this”. But a memo found in the National Archives continues: “On the other hand, neither the aircraft nor its passengers were British and it was not yet clear that many people on the ground would require assistance. “The private houses affected would presumably be covered by insurance.” There was no mention in the document that the Government should feel morally obliged to help or that it should take the lead and set up a fund.  Instead, Mrs Thatcher told colleagues the Government would make “an appropriate contribution”a fund was opened. An emergency fund was announced by the local council that same day and then Transport Secretary Paul Channon told the Commons “the Government will contribute in the normal way”. The minutes also reveal Mrs Thatcher ordered Mr Channon to spin the response to the atrocity. She said he “should give as much detail as he could about major shyoperations that were being mounted in response to this tragedy” and “it was important that it should be as positive as possible”.   The Government was soon engulfed in criticism that it failed to pass on a warning from American authorities on December  that a Pan Am flight from Frankfurt to the US could be a terror target within two weeks. Mr Channon said this information was not passed on to British airlines or airports as it had little credibility. Dr Swire, a GP who became the face of a campaign for a public inquiry into the atrocity, said of the memo: “If I had known about it at the time my first response would have been shyastonishment and fury.   “It seems callous to me and calculating that hours after the bombing the Government is counting the cost to itself, and looking at ways of minimising that cost. I would have thought that the Cabinet would have been urging their most powerful investigators to discover whether they played any part in allowing this atrocity to happen. You couldn’t make it up, could you  It is stunning.” Medical student Flora Swire, , was sitting in seat D on Pam Am Flight . Dr Swire added: “I was completely done on that day. It took me a long time to recover my voice.”   He and another Lockerbie relative claimed they were bugged as confidential documents revealed they needed “careful watching”. The grieving dad said: “They have been listening in to our communications and concealing something they didn’t want us to know.” Mrs Thatcher had been warned families were getting increasingly organised and it was suggested they should be put under observation. A letter from the Foreign Office on August , , to Lord Fraser of Carmyllie, shyScotland’s most senior law officer, said: “Another aspect which will need careful watching is the activities of relatives of Pan Am  victims.   “The US relatives have for some time been well organised and vocal. More recently the UK relatives have formed the group UK Families Flight  and have written to ious ministers. We must be totally consistent in our responses.” A copy was sent to Mrs Thatcher. The Crown Office said the criminal probe into the disaster remained live, while the Foreign Office added: “We will not be commenting on the contents of our archive files.”   Only one person has been convicted over Lockerbie, Libyan Abdelbaset al-Megrahi, jailed for le in . Co-accused Lamen Khala Fhimah was acquitted. Al-Megrahi died in , aged , after being freed on compassionate grounds three years earlier. Dr Swire and a number of British victims’ families believe he may have been wrongly convicted. In , the Mirror revealed a security guard at Heathrow – where the New York-bound plane made a stop – discovered a break in at the Pan Am baggage area on the day of the attack. This was not revealed during the trial. Libya was suspected early in the probe as former leader Muammar Gaddafi is believed to have wanted revenge for the US bombing of Tripoli in .  But the finger of blame was also pointed at Iran. In July , a US Navy warship in the Persian Gulf shot down Iran Air Flight , killing  civilians, including  children. The Lockerbie Air Disaster Fund raised pound.million, of which nearly half was spent compensating victims and the rest went on projects in the town. Libya’s regime eventually accepted responsibility for the attack and agreed in  to pay pound.billion in compensation infor the lting of international sanctions.

story: NewsMeghan Markle frustrates royal staff and falls out with sister-in-law KateMany felt she would be the breath of fresh air the royals needed, but there is a feeling of frustration developingShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video kate-middleton-speaks-meghan-over-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSix months after the Duchess of Sussex’s fairytale wedding, it appears the honeymoon could indeed be over. After initially being wowed by ex-actress Meghan, royal sources suggest people behind the scenes are now feeling the strain of her “authoritative” nature. And while many felt she would be the breath of fresh air the royals needed, there is a certain feeling of frustration developing. Rumours of a falling out with sister-in-law the Duchess of Cambridge, a frequent “abrupt tone” and her apparent demands on staff have led to the Queen intervening. And the very public fallout with her dad, followed by the rows with her extended family, have “raised more than a few eyebrows” among the family known as The Firm. Even a quiet word from Her Majesty in Harry’s ear after his apparent “What Meghan wants, Meghan gets” outburst has done little to quell the “whirlwind” blowing through the household.  With an unrelenting schedule and a perfectionist’s attitude, it is clear Meghan, , has thrown herself into royal le. One key source revealed that when she revealed her intentions to “hit the ground running”, she gained much admiration. But her attitude is since said to have changed from the “smiling, bright- eyed Meghan into something more imperious”. Others suggest she has seemed particularly keen to shed her image as an actress who did racy photoshoots and steamy sex scenes, with her former career a “total no-go area” for conversation. A source said: “On the face of it, Meghan does have it all. She’s intelligent, enthusiastic and has a dferent way of doing things, which can be very exciting. But the constant ‘go-getter’ persona is wearing thin among some members of the household. Her attitude from the off was, ‘I want to know everything’. While that’s admirable, the whirlwind nature of it all is just not possible. There is so much to get to grips with. People feel she is putting too much pressure on herself and needs to realise there’s more to royal duty than learning the steps, making speeches.   “Some staff have even discussed how they can encourage her to slow down but, so far, it has been dficult.” Details of her unrelenting schedule have emerged, revealing apparent am texts, emails and even dawn calls to staff with ious demands. Then there is the row over an emerald tiara Meghan wanted to wear for her wedding and reports emerging of a rt with the Duchess of Cambridge. Kate was reportedly reduced to tears after Princess Charlotte’s bridesmaid dress fitting in the run-up to Meghan’s May wedding. The -year-old, who had just given birth to Prince Louis, was said to be “feeling quite emotional”. Another source added: “It’s obvious the two women are pretty dferent and while they haven’t been involved in a soap opera-style falling out, they aren’t exactly the best of friends.  “But their lack of closeness could also be to do with the two brothers wanting to pursue their own lives and there’s no real desire to be spending every waking minute together.” The Daily Mirror understands Meghan and Harry’s move to Frogmore Cottage at Windsor Castle was partly to do with William’s ambitions for Kensington Palace. The couple were reportedly set to enter opulent Apartment  at the shypalace, which will be renovated after the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester shyvacate it in the new year. However, one source suggests that after William and Kate opted to remain in the palace once Charles becomes King, they also decided they want to have -room Apartment  and turn it into an array of “state rooms”. A source said: “The plan would be to use the rooms for banquets and welcoming heads of states, and honoured guests. Harry and Meghan were offered other accommodation within the palace but saw this as the perfect opportunity to get out of London and start afresh.” Though both families will keep their offices at the palace, Meghan and Harry will face a -mile comshyshymute into London. The source added: “On the one hand it’s felt the breathing space will be a good thing for all involved. But on the other, those early-morning calls just might get a little earlier.”

title: mum saved 50000 benefits payments
story: NewsMum who saved £k in benefits to enrich sons le convicted of fraudKayann Phillips, , was entitled to social security benefits but failed to declare her savings to the Department of Work and PensionsShareCommentsByLiz Day:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsKayann Phillips, , was found guilty of benefit fraud at Cardf Crown Court "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who saved up pound, in benefit payments but failed to declare them has been convicted of fraud and told she may be forced to pay the money back. Kayann Phillips, a carer for her -year-old son, was absolutely entitled to claim social security benefits between August  and September , the court heard. After building up more than pound, in savings at one point she has now been convicted of benefit fraud, reports Wales Online. Phillips, , had failed to declare the savings when applying for benefits. Speaking atCardf Crown Court, Judge Jeremy Jenkins said: “I find that this is an unusual case.” In his sentencing remarks Judge Jenkins said: “Unusually you were not spending those benefits to the full extent but you were saving part of the money you received.   “You were saving, I have no doubt, for a very noble purpose – to enrich your son’s le.” The court heard her adult son has “considerable dficulties” and she has been caring for him since he was born. Benefit claimants must inform the Department for Work and Pensionsthey have savings. The authorities then make deductions according to the amount involved. Prosecutors said at one stage Phillips had more than pound, in savings but failed to declare them on her claim forms. Judge Jenkins said: “As a result you were not entitled to the full benefits you continued to receive.” Nuhu Gobir, prosecuting, said the total overpayment was more than pound, and there will be a hearing under the Proceeds of Crime Act on February . Clare Wilks, defending, described the circumstances as “unusual” and said the Probation Service found her client to present a low risk of re-offending. The court heard the defendant only has access to her current account as her other accounts have been restrained. Judge Jenkins said: “I find that this is an unusual case, albeit the charge of fraud is clearly made out.” He noted the amount involved as “considerable” and said the forms made it “abundantly clear” the defendant should have declared any savings. The judge described Phillips as a “dedicated” mother who had previously led an “unblemished” le. He added: “You are  and you have never before come anywhere close to getting into trouble.” Phillips, from Llanharan,Pontyclun, was given a -month prison sentence suspended for  months.

Could it mean the royal tots enjoy extra presents, on top of making special memories hanging the baulbles on the tree She told theshe likes to have as many trees around the house as possible, including one in each of the grandchildrens rooms so they can decorate it themselves - sure to be the envy of Christmas fans everywhere. The future kings grandmother is said to have then taken a long pause, before admitting: That makes me sound as though I live in a mansion, doesnt it  In the y interview published today , Carole also discussed how she likes to live as normally as possible at home in Bucklebury, west Berkshire.The arguably second most famous granny on the globe didnt reveal much  about her very own Christmas tradition, and didnt rule out seven-month-old Prince Louis.There was also no mention of the newest addition to the family, Pippas one-month-old baby boy Arthur Michael William Matthews.  The royal family is known for celebrating Christmas in style and keeping up ious traditions. If you thought you were organised this year - take a leaf out of the the Queens book - she writes her cards in the summer to make sure she is extra prepared.She also asks her more than  members of staff what theyd like so she can start buying gts as early as March.Then, a week before Christmas, staff gather in the State Apartments, and one by one come forward to receive their gt from the Queen.  All of the gts are bought from just one shop - Harrods - and has been known to wander around the closed store for hours selecting presents.In recent years, it has become tradition for Princes William and Harry to play a Christmas Eve football match alongside workers from the Sandringham Estate, with the Princes always on opposing sides. They usually wear the socks of their favorite teams - Aston Villa for William and Arsenal for Harry - and they take it pretty seriously. But theres nothing serious around the red drawing room at the estate come Christmas Eve, when the royals hand each their gag gts to one another.The rule is that no-one should open their present until given permission by Philip, who supervises the proceedings, and that every present should be a cheap “joke gt”, and the cheaper the better.

story: NewsQueens Christmas decorations are up with festive season underway at Windsor CastleFans visiting the Queens Berkshire home can see a ft fir tree covered in gold decorations and around , lightsShareCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video christmas-at-windsor-castle-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The festive season has officially arrived at Windsor Castle with beautul Christmas trees and decorations going on display today.November traditionally sees the start of the Christmas adverts for the major retailers, but it seems even the royals are getting in on the act early this year.Open to visitors from Saturday, December , the amazing creations were created by royal staff.Fans visiting the Queens Berkshire home can see a ft fir tree covered in gold decorations and around , lights in the castles majestic St Georges Hall.  Staff from the Royal Household have spent the past few days erecting the tree, a smaller fir in the nearby crimson drawing room, and other decorations throughout the state apartments to celebrate Christmas.Richard Williams, the Royal Collection Trusts learning curator, said: The huge tree in St Georges Hall is from the Windsor Great Park, so its actually grown in the grounds surrounding the castle.  Its a Nordmann Fir and it has something like , separate lights on it, so its a major, major scale, it took a day and a half to decorate so teams were up very, very tall ladders.Its very much for visitors, there are large numbers of people who go to the Royal Collection Trust website to see when the decorations are up because for many people it marks the start of Christmas.  Queen Charlotte, the German-born we of George III, is credited with introducing the Christmas tree to Britain.But it was Prince Albert who popularised it, presenting large numbers to schools and Army barracks, and when a print was published in  showing the royal family around the festive emblem, its use escalated throughout society.  While most people open their presents on Christmas Day, the current royal family still keep to the German practice of unwrapping their gts on Christmas Eve.The Queen, Duke of Edinburgh and other royals usually congregate in the White Drawing Room at Sandringham House around a ft tree, cut from the estate, for the exchange of presents displayed nearby on a white linen-covered trestle table.

title: woman buying sanitary products instead
story: NewsWoman is buying sanitary products instead of gts for her family this ChristmasElla Daish is tackling period poverty with a reverse advent calendar, adding eco-friendly sanitary products from December  to Christmas DayShareCommentsByKatie-Ann GupwellKelly-Ann Mills:,  NOV NewsElla Daish wants to do something dferent this year "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman has decided not to buy gts for her family this Christmas and is spending her money on sanitary products instead. Ella Daish, , hit the headlines back in July when she spoke out about her desire for more women to use eco-friendly sanitary products. Over the past year she has been campaigning for more women to use eco-friendly alternatives. When working as a postwoman in the Vale of Glamorgan she was appalled by the volume of rubbish on the streets on refuse collection day. It made her reflect on the types of products she was using as a woman and she decided to take a stand. Ella, from Cardf, has decided to do something to tackle the issue of period poverty this Christmas. She said: Ive met lots of people over the last year, and heard lots of dferent stories about period poverty, and I was starting to think about Christmas.  Instead of spending money on Christmas presents for my family Im spending it on eco period products to give to people in period poverty. Its not something people should have to go through. Its wrong that people are faced by it. A study by sanitary product company Always revealed that more than , girls miss out on school each year because they lack access to sanitary protection. In March  a survey carried out by childrens charity Plan UK revealed that two fths of girls admitted to relying on using toilet roll at some point to help control their period - simply because they have been unable to afford sanitary products. During the investigation the charity interviewed , girls and women between the ages of  and , and it revealed % of the participants who had started their period confirmed they have had no option but to make their own sanitary-wear. Shockingly, up to % of girls also said they had used socks, other materials or things like newspaper to try and manage when they are menstruating. To try and help tackle the issue, Ella has invented her own unique advent calendars to try and help women in need - and she wants other people to get on board.  Ella says you can make any type of box at home. Using a cardboard box, every day between December  and December  you add an eco-friendly sanitary product to her reverse advent calendar. Ella hopes to fill a number of boxes herself but is encouraging others to join her however they can. Im putting products in a day, but I dont expect everyone to do that, she added. How people do it is up to you. You can put one product in a box or a packets of pads - its up to you. Its quite a lot for people to give. I am doing it this way but Im not giving anyone Christmas presents this year - Im just doing this instead. Its the money I would have spent on gts for my family. Ellas homemade calendars, dubbed the Eco Period Box, can be made with any old box at home. But shes encouraging people to use environmentally friendly products to aid her initial campaign. Following months of campaigns from people like Ella, eco-friendly products are now available in major supermarkets like Tesco and Sainsburys.  She says they are around the same price as major branding products - but they wont be as cheap as supermarket versions. Ella added: I want to address poverty, but I want to address it in my own way. I believe everyone deserves a choice in what they use which is why I am doing this. This is why I wanted to promote eco-products. Im so passionate about this because period poverty shouldnt be impacting people. It shouldnt prevent people from getting an education and they shouldnt have to miss out. It shouldnt exist in  which is the reason I started the period box. Christmas is a time where we give so why not donate a gt of this - especially during the festive season when people need them. The Eco Period Box scheme will start on December  and end on December . At the end of the month the boxes can be donated to charities such as the Red Box Project, Bloody Good Period, Freedom  Girls and local food banks such as the Trussell Trust.

They don’t really care or they just assume that they are doing it right and women are very complex creatures.” Vince added: “Wesleigh is very intimate, she is very loving, she treats me like a man, she makes sure that all of my needs are met, she also makes me feel loved which is very important, sex without love is not really a connection.” Wesleigh has always been interested in older men and was looking for a protective, older male figure to fill the emotional void left when her father died when she was a child. And when she met Vince she fell straight in love with him because he is a dferent type of man.”  But Vince had never dated signicantly younger women and admitted that this is his first age gap relationship. He said: “I was attracted to her blonde hair, she had a beautul smile and then, of course, she used the word Disney in her profile and I thought well, she has to be a Disney fan, otherwise everything is off, because I’m kind of a Disney aficionado. “I have never really thought that it would be a long-term thing. “There were some things in my previous marriage that were lacking and I felt that a younger girl would be able to provide those for me, but at the time I didn’t realise that I was going to fall so hard for Wesleigh.”  Wesleigh’s mother, Paige - who is only a year younger than her son-in-law - said that it took her a while to get used to her daughter’s husband, even though she knew that Wesleigh has always been interested in older men. Paige said: “Wesleigh has never done anything by the book. As a mom, you want your kids to comply but you want them to do their own thing and find their own place. The couple, from Little Rock, Arkansas, admit that their romance has raised some eyebrows.  Wesleigh said: “A lot of middle-aged women think that I am with Vince just for money, because of the way I look. “I feel likeI look dferent then your typical cheerleader or whatever girl next door then we probably wouldn’t get as many nasty looks.” Vince added: “To be someone younger especially that much,  years younger than you it’s not the norm and when things are not the norm many people will feel uncomfortable, just dont want to associate with you.” Doctors told the couple they may have trouble having children, so when Wesleigh fell pregnant, it was a very pleasant surprise for both parents. And Wesleigh says that motherhood has changed her. Vince is orced and has a -year-old son, Jeff, who, according to the couple, gets along very well with his new younger stepmother.  Speaking about what the future might bring, Vince said: “Having the age gap and knowing that I have a young we and a very young daughter at my age, the depressing part for me is the fact that I won’t be able to see her as a grown up and maybe I won’t be able to see her having children.” Wesleigh said: “I have somebody that is constantly guiding me in the right direction. If I need advice I don’t really need to go to my mom, I can go to Vince. I have somebody there to constantly provide support for me which I wouldn’t getI was with somebody of my own age.” Vince added: “I have a number of dferent hats now as supposed to just being a husband, I kind of feel like I am a mentor. I feel like I can teach and bring items into Wesleigh’s le that I have gone through and my experiences to somewhat make her a better person.”

title: mum asks knee length dress
story: NewsMum asksdress is appropriate for funeral after husband says its "too much"The woman was planning to wear a black wrap dress which is "practically knee " on her because shes only ft tall from ASOSShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsIt can be hard to know what to wear"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDressing for a funeral can be dficult, especiallyyou dont know your loved-ones friends or family too well. You want to look smart while being comfortable, without doing anything which could upset or offend any other mourners. One woman found herself in this dilemma after her husband told her the dress she was planning to wear to a funeral wasnt appropriate. The anonymous mum picked a black wrap dress which is practically kneeon her because shes only ft tall from ASOS - but he said it was too much. She shared a photo of the dress on the parenting website Mumsnet to see what other people thought. She wrote: AIBU [am I being unreasonable] to wear this dress to a funeral   I already have this dress and have a funeral next week. I intend to wear it with black tights and black ankle boots with a small heel. Also I am  foot tall so it is practically kneeon me.I thought it was perfect but DH [darling husband] seems to think its too much.She later added: Ive worn it before and it doesnt gape, it fits nice. I did consider it maybe looking too dressy but I thought opaque black tights and a neutral tone scarf would make it a little more daytime Also its certainly not what I would wear of a night out but I am a fairly formal dresser, I wear similar dresses on weekends. Her dilemma caused a debate online with parents sharing very dferent opinions on the dress. Many believed it was completely fine, especially as shes planning to wear tights. One wrote: Keep jewellery and make-up simple and make sure the tights are opaque. Its totally fine.  While another said: I think its absolutely fine. I also have noticed more recently that fewer people of all ages actually wear black. One woman pointed out: I think most people who are bereaved dont even notice what people are wearing. Its fine it you put some black tights with it. But others disagreed and thought she should find something  to wear. One mum wrote: Hmm, I dont really think its suitable funeral attire either. Its the sort of style Id wear on a night out. Another member replied: Its a bit frilly for a funeral for me. Id wear something plainer tbh. To the bemusement of a number of other commenters, one person suggested: It is a bit short for a funeral tbh. DO you have a pair of black jeans or trousers you could wear underneath  That would be more suitable than tights. Also could you wear a vest or crew neck Tshirt underneath  If not then perhaps a broach at the top of the neckline to close it  Any other situation it would be lovely but I feel that there is a bit more flesh on show than there should be for a funeral, lovely though it is. In the end it seems the woman decided to wear the dress, thanking parents for their advice. She wrote: Thank you everyone! I feel alot better, I havent been to a funeral before so was unsure. Also, I promise not to pout or wear jeans underneath.

title: shocking moment man names girlfriend
story: NewsMan reveals shock name of his killer as he lays on floor moments before dyingWARNING - DISTRESSING CONTENT: Shocking video was shown to court of the moment Larry Atwood named his long-term girlfriend as his killerShareCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video she-shot-me-texas-court-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe horric moment a man named his girlfriend as his killer as he lay dying in a road has been played to court. Distressing footage showed Larry Atwood covered in blood suffering from a gunshot wound to the stomach. In it, Mr Atwood covers his head as blood pours on the ground, he says he was shot by Elizabeth Taylor and gives her address as Cooks Lake Road. He was also heard saying: Help me, help me, she shot me. The court heard Taylor,  and her younger partner Mr Atwood, , had been driving along a motorway in Texas, when she shot him and drove away.  Monster who stabbed his we  times blamed cough medicine Taylor claimed she shot Mr Atwood in self defence when he had hit her, grabbed her hair and tried to suffocate her while they were in the car. She claimed to have grabbed the gun from her bag and shot towards the windscreen, but she shot him in the stomach.  She told the court that she had warned her boyfriend, telling him You put your hands on me again, Im going to shoot you. Im not going to let you do that again and get away with it. Prosecutors say Taylor left Mr Atwood dying in the road, while she drove to her sons house. Her son, David Walters, gave evidence and told the court his mother arrived with a black eye, swollen cheeks and a cut nose.  She told him: I think I might be in trouble. I mightve shot Larry. The jury deliberated for five hours, before finding Taylor guilty of murder as she cried hysterically, reports KDFM. She was sentenced to just four years in prison after an agreement between prosecutors and the defence. She will become eligible for parole in two years. The defence waived the right to a jury punishment and Judge John Stevens sentenced Taylor today.

title: all aboard new buses
story: Bus firm Xplore Dundee has confirmed it will roll out contactless payments after it launched a new fleet of vehicles.The company is set to install new Ticketer machines that will “speed up and modernise” services, starting from Sunday.The machines will first appear on Xplore’s new  buses – nicknamed “Emerald” – before being installed on older vehicles.The new equipment will help drivers manage arrival and departure times, print tickets faster and by January will accept payments by debit card and smartphone.Managing director Christine McGlasson said: “We’re busy training our drivers right now so that they know how to use the new equipment and will be able to guide customers.“Security will be improved for paper tickets as they’ll come with a QR code, which you just need to scan under the reader when you hop on the bus.“However, passengers shouldn’t notice much of a dference in buying and receiving their tickets, apart from the process becoming quicker, smoother and more secure.”The hardware will be updated to support contactless payments from the end of January.Ms McGlasson added: “These new ticket machines are the first major step towards contactless payment and we hope to be able to complete the process early next year.”The Emerald buses are eco-friendly hybrids which are claimed to reduce emissions by %.Passenger comforts include extra legroom, comfier seats, USB chargers, wi and audio visual next-stop announcements.The new buses were due to be shown off in City Square today, with the first  visitors being treated to Xplore-themed coffee and cakes, courtesy of Blend Coffee Lounge and Clark’s Bakery.

title: dee boss macca demands more of men ahead of hectic schedule
story: As he works to turn Dundee’s season round, boss Jim McIntyre has told his players to speak up – when things go right as well as wrong.Jim himself has never been slow to let players from the technical area knowthey’ve not been pulling their weight.He also believes praise, when praise is due, must be dished out.And he wants that attitude to spill over onto the pitch during games and even in training.“We need to be demanding of each other. It can’t just come from the manager, it’s got to come from the players who are on the park,” he said.“That’s what we’ve been encouraging since we came in the door.“If somebody needs a rocket, then they get it, but encourage after that.“If they need told ‘you need to do better’, then tell them. That’s a big part of the game, but then it’s got to be equal measure of praise as well and that’s important.”It’s something Jim wants from his squad as a whole because he knows most will be called into action during a December programme that will bring seven games in just three-and-a-half weeks.A run of games that starts with Hamilton on Wednesday and ends with the pre-winter break Tayside derby against St Johnstone on December , will stretch resources but the gaffer is viewing it as a chance to pick up vital points.“It’s the same for everyone. It’s just about making sure you are recovering well between games and getting ready to go. There’s not a lot of turn around between games.“It’s an opportunity for us to maximise as many points as we can and get back into the pack.“But we’re going to need every one of the squad.“It’s a tough, tough period and there will be times when we just make changes simply because we need to freshen it, not just based on the performance.”Between now and the winter break, Jim will pay particular attention to his “over s” like Darren O’Dea, Martin Woods, Paul McGowan and Kenny Miller.At , striker Miller is comfortably the old man of the Dens Park squad.Jim, though, knows ultimately their experience will help tell them how their bodies are and whether or not they need a break from games or even training.“As a manager, I’ve always made sure that I look after the older players in the group.“I think when you are that age it’s your mentality, you know what it takes to get yourself through a game.“You know what you need to do to recover, you know how your body is.“Equally, you know when to say ‘here we go again’, it’s game time and let’s get ourselves going.”Dundee’s U s are in action this evening when they travel to take on Hearts at the Oriam .And their Youth Cup cash with Clachnacuddin takes place at Station Park on Sunday week.

title: dream becomes a reality for charity
story: Dundee’s first dedicated virtual realitycentre is gearing up to open in a week’s time.Showcase VR has been created by social enterprise Showcase the Street in order to put high-tech virtual reality gear within reach of those who might not be able to afford it. vw, px"   vw, px"  From interactive VR experiences through to -degree video, the project – at Manhattan Works – aims to offer something for seasoned tech fans as well as those trying VR for the first time.It’s also a new initiative for Showcase, best-known for giving kids from all walks of le access to activities such as dance classes and football coaching.Raymond Chan, Showcase’s VR development officer, said the new facility remains true to their mission of bringing creative arts to young people from all backgrounds. vw, px"   vw, px"   vw, px"  He said: “We could possibly be the cheapest VR arcade in the UK. We aim to be accessible and inclusive for everyone.“It’s not just games. If people like to be creative they can paint in D using a program called TiltBrush.“We’ve got a wide range of activities for people of all types of mobility and we’re wheelchair-friendly as well.”About £, has been invested in the latest high-tech VR equipment, courtesy of funding from a number of sources, including Resilient Scotland.The facility is ided into five zones offering dferent virtual experiences.Some of the equipment on offer includes HTC Vive headsets – which cost £ apiece – and handheld controllers that translate real-world arm movements like throwing and grabbing into interactive games.One of the most astonishing investments is a set of Katwalk VR treadmills that can be “walked” on while staying still.It even supports vertical body movement – so you can sit down and appreciate your virtual environment.Another zone features vibrating floor plates which can add to the sense of immersion.When combined with moments such as an intense Second World War bombing raid in the videogame Battlefield V, it means people can feel they are really “in” their games.Showcase VR also boasts two motion-sensitive steering wheel set-ups which can tilt forwards, backwards and side-to-side – ideal for intense racing simulators. Despite the massive investment, Showcase is keeping prices at a minimum to ensure as many people as possible can enjoy the gadgets on offer.One-hour sessions for up to three people are £, while up to  people can play for two hours for £, including food.Fergus Storrier, director of Showcase the Street, said the VR facilities were about more than giving underprivileged children access to computer games.“It has been a real community effort – like everything we do,” he said.“We’ve had Adam Milroy and Ian Tayac in to do the graffiti art on the walls – they do all of that type of art for us.“We’re already working with Abertay on a project to create a VR game that aims to improve people’s employability skills.”Showcase VR opens next week. For more information visit facebook ShowcaseVR.

title: dundees jesse curran puts scotland philippines and australia talk to one side
story: Just four-and-a-bit months after breaking into the first team on a regular basis, and at ,  didn’t think he’d be deciding his international future.Already, though, the opening skirmishes have taken place in what’s become a two-way fight to secure his services.Andthe level of performance he put in at Hibs at the weekend that saw him praised by both managers on duty continues, a third country could soon be battling to tie him down.As was reported recently, the Philippines are making overtures to get Curran to commit to themand the midfielder has revealed representatives from the land of his birth, Australia, have also watched him.Last, but certainly not least, the fact he’s doing so well in the Premiership here might just see Alex McLeish want to persuade him to pledge allegiance to Scotland.At such an early stage of his career, and with no actual call-ups to any squads so far, he is taking nothing for granted.But while, for him, it’s just hugely flattering to be linked with a step up to international level, he admitsthat situation arises, it’s only after careful consideration that he’ll decide which country to pledge allegiance to.“I am just going to see how things unfold,” is the sensible answer he gives when quizzed about the matter.“I was asked to go to the Philippines training camp, not to commit to anything, just to see the facilities, meet the people and the staff and stuff like that.“It is a good opportunity, they’ve got the Asian Cup coming up in a couple of months so it’s something to look towards.“But I have the Socceroosto look to as well and Scotland too, so it’s a big decision. It’s a career decision so I am not going to rush into anything.“When I first started getting in the Dundee first team this season, the Socceroos came to one of my games and that was a big positive for me because I hadn’t been playing that long.“I will see how it plays out but it’s not something I expected to be thinking about right now. It’s great for me and, hopefully, I can just keep progressing.”Lightning quick on the pitch, when asked which of the countries would be his first choice, he shows he’s not slow either when it comes to coming up with a diplomatic answer.“I don’t really want to say. I’m from Australia and was brought up there so it would, obviously, be good to play from them.“But my dad is Scottish and my mum’s from the Philippines so they matter to me as well.“I just have to see who,anyone, comes for me and then take things from there.”The good news for Dark Blues fans is he’s fully focused on their team right now and helping with the fight to climb off the bottom of the top flight.And he’s convinced that draw at Hibs was the strongest evidence yet, in terms of both commitment and quality, Dundee have what it takes to do that.“To come back from - down to - is a great positive for us.“It was good, especially at a place like Easter Road because when Hibs get ahead they can control the game.“We had the chances to go and win the game, to be fair both teams did, so it was quite an entertaining game and it was a good game to play in.“Just a couple of balls in the final third let us down but we’ll work on that.“Obviously, St Mirren won at the weekend and the gap is three points but we are going to look at our performance and will keep working hard to make sure that’s how we play. We have to concentrate on ourselves.”

title: dundee united to offer christmas day meal at tannadice to 120 lonely city folk
story: Dundee United are offering a free Christmas Day meal to  lonely city residents.The Dundee United Community Trust is this year opening up the doors of Tannadice to local residents who may otherwise be on their own.The trust is working with The Ambassador pub in Clepington Road to extend the festivities, with more food and activities planned into the afternoon with the event running from am to pm on December .A club statement said: #We are also working on transport to assist with getting our guests to and from the event.#There are still places left and we would really encourage you to get in touchyou know of anyone who would benefit from coming along. Perhaps a neighbour or family friend who doesn’t get out much.#The community trust would also welcome donations from businesses or iniduals of gts that we can give to our guests to give them a fantastic Christmas Day.#Festive Friends is the result of cash raised from the Team DUCT Kiltwalkers earlier in the year and funding from the SPFL Trust.Should you wish to donate a gt, email the community trust at michael.malone@dundeeunitedct.

title: ex dundee midfielder nick ross going loco with us move in bid for mls promotion
story: Former Dundee midfielder Nick Ross hopes his move to American second-tier side El Paso Locomotive can provide a lucrative stepping stone to Major League Soccer.After ending a short stint with Brora Rangers, Ross sealed a move to the newly-formed Texas outfit yesterday on a one-year contract with the option of a further year.The -year-old will report for pre-season with El Paso in January as the club prepares for its  debut in the USL Championship.Although no promotion to the ring-fenced MLS is available, former Scotland U  international Ross hopes making an impression at his new club may catch the eye of clubs higher up the American ladder.Ross said: “I’m just looking forward to getting over and seeing how the year goes.“If I play well over there the target is to get into the MLS but that’s everybody’s target so it’s not that easy.There are a lot of good teams at this level. Before he retired recently, Didier Drogba was playing at this level for Phoenix Rising.“There’s no promotion, which is maybe the only downfall. Butyou can get yourself into an MLS team, with the way it’s going and the money they are putting into it, it’s going to be huge.“With David Beckham getting a team, in the next few years it’s going to be really big.”Before this move, Ross also had a brief stint in Romania with Sepsi Sfantu Gheorghe last summer.He said: “In football you are so fortunate, you can try to go anywhere in the world and play football.“I just thought I would try something dferent. That’s why I ended up in Romania and now I’m going to America.”

story: The festive feeling is arriving in Tealing this weekend with a Christmas fair and the switch-on of the tree lights.The event at the village hall on Sunday marks the start of the festive season.There will be creative and craft market stalls and goodies including home baking, a Christmas cafe at which to grab a drink and mince pie and a prize raffle.There will also be carol singing and a singalong with schoolchildren and their parents.Santa and his elves will also be paying a visit.The event take place at Tealing Hall, Inveraldie, from -pm.The Christmas tree lights will be switched on at .pm by the new head teacher of Tealing Primary, Michael Smith.Entry is by donation and all proceeds will be used to benefit the local community.

title: i wanted to stay conscious i had to remember him
story: A woman who was subjected to a brutal assault at the hands of a killer has revealed for the first time how she “played dead” in a bid to make her attacker go away.Linda McDonald, a mum and grandmother, was walking her Jack Russell terrier Betsy in Templeton Woods in August last year when Robbie McIntosh attacked her while on home leave from prison.In her first in-depth interview since the incident which shocked the city, the -year-old recalled the harrowing and astonishing details of the attack.Linda has taken the courageous decision to let us publish some photos of those injuries – though we have censored one and others were too horric to release.#I am sharing these photos to show how viciously I was attacked,# she said. vw, px"  vw, px"  She told how she pleaded with McIntosh not to hurt her, how his face remained expressionless and devoid of emotion as he repeatedly hit her with a dumbbell, and how she feared she was going to be raped.Linda also revealed how, incredibly, she fought to stay conscious in the aftermath of the attack in order to give police a description of her attacker, in case she didn’t survive and he got away with the crime.Recalling the moments immediately after McIntosh struck, Linda said: “I thought thatI stopped breathing and played dead it would finish and he would go away.“I said a prayer to God and went somewhere  peaceful in my own mind to remove myself from what was happening to me.”Linda said that the day had started normally enough and she took Betsy for a walk in the woods as she had done countless times before.She said: “I met a few people and then I was aware of this man walking towards me.“I can’t explain why but immediately I had a bad feeling.“My sixth sense told me that something wasn’t right and I was very uncomfortable.“He was a really tall figure and he had a military-style march.“I had a really strange feeling about him. It was a relief when he passed me by, but next thing I heard loud, heavy footsteps behind me.“There was a nanosecond of silence when the footsteps stopped and I just knew that something bad was going to happen.“I turned around and he was running towards me.“I had no chance to react before he struck me on the right-hand side of my head.“The blow stunned me and immediately I felt lethargic but I also realised immediately that I was going to have to fightI was going to survive.”It was at that moment that Linda pleaded with MscIntosh not to go through with whatever he had planned.She added: “I said to him: ‘Please don’t do this’.“He was expressionless but he also looked like he was enjoying me begging for my le.“I knew he was going to strike again and I decided I was going to have to scream and make a noise.“Then the blows continued and I felt warm blood.“I couldn’t see and thought I was going blind.”#Le should mean le#: Dundee killer Robbie McIntosh#s victim out to ensure he is NEVER released" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp le-should-mean-le-dundee-killer-robbie-mcintoshs-victim-out-to-ensure-he-is-never-released embed # secrethIGSeyC" data-secret"hIGSeyC" width"" "" title"##Le should mean le#: Dundee killer Robbie McIntosh#s victim out to ensure he is NEVER released# # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Linda recalled that McIntosh then grabbed hold of her ankles as she lay on the ground and dragged her off the path and into a wooded area.“I must have passed out because I came round and was aware I was on my tummy, being dragged very quickly into the wood,” she said.“The clothes on my upper body were off and I thought he was going to rape me. He was leaning over me and it was at this point I decided to stop breathing and play dead.“I took myself somewhere  and at that point I felt peaceful and had no pain. I thought about my family and how distressed they would beI left them.“I prayed to God and above all  I was determined that I would live to be able to describe my attacker so that he wasn’t able to do it to anyone  ever again.“I knew I would have to fight to stay conscious to remember as much as possible.“My overriding thought was to make sure that I could describe every detail of that man. I had to make sure he was caught.” vw, px"   vw, px"   vw, px"  The next thing Linda can recall is two men anxiously leaning over her, and that her attacker had gone.The two men, fellow dog-walkers Charles and Peter Connor, helped raise the alarm.A huge number of police officers rushed to the scene, immediately launching a massive manhunt for the person responsible and tending to seriously-injured Linda.They made an arrest shortly after in the village of Bridgefoot, north of Dundee – and the suspect was revealed to be McIntosh, aged  at the time.Robbie McIntosh attacked Linda McDonald with a dumbbell as she was walking her dog in Templeton Woods.The attack happened five days after he was allowed out of prison on home leave, about  years after he had murdered another dog walker, Anne Nicoll, , on the city’s Law by stabbing her to death.McIntosh, who has “psychopathic traits”, was jailed in  for a minimum of  years for the murder of civil servant Miss Nicoll.But he was allowed home for a week’s leave on the th anniversary of the murder as he was being prepared for release.After just five days of freedom he put a dumbbell in a rucksack and set out from his home to carry out another horric attack with chilling similarities to his original crime.Just three days after the attack, he had been due to appear at a parole hearing at which he could have been freed from prison.Lord Arthurson imposed an order for lelong restriction on McIntosh at the High Court in Aberdeen after he pleaded guilty to attempted murder.Although he was told he must serve at least five years before he can be considered for parole, the order effectively acts as a le sentence as he can only be freed when the parole board approves his release.He was warned by the judge that he may never be freed and sources said he was likely to spend “decades” in custody.The case is also the subject of a review over whether he was suitable for home leave.

title: new lease of life for eyesore shops
story: The owner of a row of derelict shops on a city street is “actively” looking at redeveloping them – and wants community input.Glasgow-based property firm Purewal Properties hopes to revamp the Macalpine shopping centre on the corner of Macalpine Road and Camperdown Road, rather than demolishing it.In a letter to Dundee City Council, representatives of the firm – which has owned the shops for  years – said surveys were being carried out on site.They said the firm was open to consulting with residents on what the block should look like in the future.The letter said: “My clientshave been actively reviewing options for redevelopment of the lower block at the centre .“In fact, they are currently awaiting an update report from their building surveyors on costings before deciding on the best option.”The letter said a planning team would engage with the council over possible uses – adding any development would likely be for commercial and retail use.The letter added: “In the interim, I am sure my clients would welcome any constructive input from the community on the type of uses or development that they consider would be beneficial.”Units in the block north of - Macalpine Road have all been refurbished in recent years but the last block has been left untouched and has fallen into disrepairThe prospect of demolition and rebuilding the site has not yet been completely ruled out.John Bisset, a community campaigner and Ardler resident, said: “I’m looking forward to seeing new properties and shops and the employment they will bring for local people.“I believe a lot of work will need to be done inside and it could even lead to the building being demolished – but evenit means rebuilding it is really welcome news.”Ward councillor Kevin Keenan said: “I welcome the news that something is going to be done to redevelop the shops.“I hope this comes to fruition and we see that area regenerated. We will keep a watching brief on what’s happening there and keep it on the agenda of the Local Community Planning Partnership to be discussed again at our next meeting, when I hope there will be a further update.”

title: oor wullie%e2%80%8b going back on the trail
story: Oor Wullie was the centre of attention in his home city as the first national bucket trail starring the cheeky comic book character was launched in Dundee.A total of  Oor Wullie sculptures will take to the streets of the City of Discovery, along with Aberdeen, Inverness, Edinburgh and Glasgow, next summer.Oor Wullie’s Big Bucket Trail will raise money for the Archie Foundation, as well as Edinburgh Children’s Hospital Charity and Glasgow Children’s Hospital Charity.In Dundee,  sculptures will be on display at ious locations from June to September, before being auctioned off to raise money for the Archie Foundation – the official charity of Tayside Children’s Hospital.The launch at DC Thomson’s Meadowside offices follows the success of the original trail held in Dundee in , which raised more than £,.David Wood, chief executive of the Archie Foundation, said: “The people of Dundee really took the first Oor Wullie’s Bucket Trail to their hearts back in  and we know they’ll do the same when the new Oor Wullies are on the streets next summer.”

story: You would have to feel that Celtics win over Rosenborg in Norway just sets them up nicely now for going into the Betfred League Cup final. There is a big call to be made on just who starts the game but I just wonderBrendan Rodgers will stick with a winning team and filed the same starting XI against Aberdeen as he did against Rosenborg. It is a huge call. Scott Brown has some game time under his belt but whether that is sufficient or not to go and play in a Cup Final is a decision that only the manager can make. But certainly in terms of the game itself, I just cant really see past Celtic. Of course, you never know what can happen in a one-off game. If you look at the  Scottish Cup final it took a moment of magic from Tom Rogic to go and win it for Celtic but I just think that just now the Parkhead side have really found their form. I wonder tooAberdeens defeat last weekend might just mean that there arent quite as positive in the game. They might be a little cageythey are wary of giving Celtic an early foothold in the game. But the way Celtic are playing at the minute, you have to fancy them. It is quite a turnaround from the opening weeks of the season. All of a sudden now you are looking at finishing the year off on a real high.
